Award.AwardTitle: Career: Catalytic Production of H2 from Water by Molecular Metal Complexes with Pentadentate Ligands
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Catalysis program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Xuan Zhao of the University of Memphis is developing new catalysts for the generation of hydrogen (an important chemical feedstock and future fuel) from water and sunlight. To accomplish this, new catalysts that are based on economically attractive metals such as cobalt are being developed. Additionally, the details of how the catalysts function are being determined. This information will provide a guide to form yet more efficient materials to convert water to hydrogen and may be applied to other potential applications such as the reduction of carbon dioxide. The project involves the training of undergraduate and graduate students in catalytic science. An outreach program will provide Memphis area students and faculty at predominantly undergraduate institutions with opportunities to participate in renewable energy research and to learn about solar energy conversion and photocatalysis through weekend workshops, summer research opportunities and local meetings.


The central hypothesis of this project is that the complexation of a metal ion by a single polydentate ligand that leaves one open site on the metal will result in stable metal complexes with high catalytic activity toward the photocatalytic reduction of water. The research centers largely on cobalt complexes for which preliminary data supports the hypothesis, but includes other earth abundant metals. In addition to synthetic studies aimed at forming these complexes with a variety of ligands, a detailed mechanistic investigation is being carried out to determine the active species for proton binding and reduction, whether H-H formation occurs through a homolytic or heterolytic pathway, and the general factors that control the mechanism of H2 evolution. The mechanistic studies are being conducted in collaboration with research scientists at Brookhaven National Laboratory.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This CAREER project seeks to understand the fundamentals of the catalytic hydrogen production by molecular cobalt complexes with pentadentate ligands, use this understanding to synthesize metal complexes with superior activity and stability for catalytic production of hydrogen in aqueous solution, and study the structure-function relationship in catalytic hydrogen production. The syntheses, characterizations, and mechanistic studies of novel types of ligand scaffolds and their cobalt complexes provide important insights into the mechanisms of hydrogen production by cobalt complexes, and provide guidelines on how to control the catalytic properties such as overpotentials and turnover frequencies of cobalt complexes for hydrogen production. The resulting knowledge obtained may facilitate the discovery of novel metal catalysts and elucidate how the electronic and steric features of ligand framework will impact the reactivity of metal catalysts for hydrogen production in the context of practical applications in energy conversion.

Intellectual Merit. This project studied a variety of molecular cobalt complexes supported by pentadentate ligands for the electro- and photocatalytic hydrogen production in aqueous solutions. The most active cobalt complex discovered in this project displays electro- and photocatalytic hydrogen production in neutral water with turnover numbers of 266,300 and 15,000, respectively, which are among the highest reported in literature for hydrogen production mediated by molecular cobalt complexes in aqueous solutions. The observation that a softer and more conjugated ligand framework leads to a more durable and active catalyst for hydrogen production provides guidelines to construct highly active water-stable catalysts with potentials for future hydrogen production. Collaborative mechanistic studies of hydrogen evolution mediated by cobalt complexes, through the application of transient spectroscopic techniques, identified the formation of highly reactive cobalt(I) and cobalt(III)-hydride intermediates during electro- and photocatalytic hydrogen production. Density functional theory computations suggest a general electron transfer−proton transfer−electron transfer−proton transfer pathway for heterolytic hydrogen formation catalyzed by the cobalt complexes investigated in this project.  

Broader Impacts. The fundamental knowledge produced by this project has the potential to contribute to the future hydrogen production with well-defined metal catalysts for a wide range of applications, including the reduction of carbon dioxide, the oxidation of water, the functionalization of hydrocarbons, solar energy conversion, and catalysis in green chemistry. This project has provided hands-on experience for undergraduate students and mentoring opportunities for graduate students and visiting professors. The summer research program involved twenty undergraduate students from Christian Brother University, Arkansas State University, Rust College and University of Memphis, among which 57% are female and 43% are African American. Their research outcomes have been presented at national and international meetings and in publications. The undergraduate workshops on artificial photosynthesis, solar energy conversion and fuel cells design have engaged 110 participants from the Memphis area and the states of Alabama, Arkansas, Mississippi, Louisiana and Missouri, including University of Mississippi, University of Tennessee at Martin, Rust College, University of New Orleans, Saint Louis University, Union University, University of North Alabama, University of Alabama, Middle Tennessee State University, University of Central Missouri, Shorter College, Philander Smith College, University of Central Arkansas, and University of Memphis. Data analysis of the workshop survey showed that about 88% of the participants agreed that the workshops have enhanced their interest in catalysis and renewable energy research, and 64% of the participants agreed that the workshops have inspired them to consider pursuing graduate studies in the area of catalysis and renewable energy research.

  

 


Last Modified: 11/13/2020
Modified by: Xuan Zhao
